content.question: A cup of coffee is poured, and the temperature is measured to be 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature of the coffee then decreases at a rate modeled by <math alttext="r of t, equals, 55 times e raised to the negative 0.03 times t squared, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>55</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.03</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> degrees Fahrenheit per minute, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of minutes since the coffee was poured. What is the temperature of the coffee, in degrees Fahrenheit, at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minute?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
